5 Electronic components
For suppliers who develop and/or produce, assemble or test electronic components (particularly
semiconductor devices, passive components and LED components) the additional, specific requirements
described in section 5 shall be applied
5.1 AECQ
Suppliers who develop and/or produce, assemble or test electronic components shall at a minimum
fulfill the respective qualification standard from the Automotive Electronics Council (AEC; e.g. AECQ 100;
AECQ 101; AECQ 200). Exceptions or deviations to above, shall be communicated to and agreed with
YAZAKI .
5.2 IPC Standards
IPC enables reliable, high-quality electronics by developing the trusted standards that drive the global
electronics industry's success. Implemented industry-wide, our standards simply communicate and
clarify expectations for everyone within the industry. IPC standards help ensure superior quality,
reliability and consistency in electronics manufacturing. (https://ipc.org/).
Consider the requirements of last issued IPC Tree to the comparable mode of component type (ex. PCB
Panel, Full Assembly PCB)
5.3 Robustness Validation
The supplier shall provide their approach to robustness validation in the development phase. In addition,
the procedure of robustness validation shall be made available to YAZAKI  for review and approval. For
further information, refer to ZVEI – Handbook of Robustness Validation.
5.4 Mission Profile for Electronic Components
YAZAKI  may issue a series of work documents to be considered by the supplier:
• Mission Profile
• Statement of Work (SOW) and/or
• Manufacturing Process items at customer (PCB Assembly, Displays, etc Technical Manufacturing
Rules and Conditions)
• Technical Cleanliness Requirements according VDA19

5.5 Software and Components with Embedded Software
Suppliers who develop or supply software or electronic components with integrated software shall
demonstrate the capability of their software development process according to Automotive SPICE or an
equivalent standard. Unless otherwise agreed, the software development capability level 3 needs to be
fulfilled according to the VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) Volume “Automotive SPICE Process Assessment Model” for processes
which are part of the “VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) process scope.
YAZAKI  retains the right to carry out an assessment at the supplier’s location.
If the agreed software development process capability level cannot be achieved, the supplier shall
provide an action plan including an adequate time schedule to achieve the agreed software
development process capability level.”
5.6 Functional Safety
When safety-relevant electronics and/or software (product or services) are included in the scope of
supply, then supplier shall be “state-of-the-art” and comply with ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 26262.
Safety-relevant parts, their documentation and the drawings shall be marked as such so that they can
be clearly identified throughout the development phase and series production process.
On RFQ (Request for Quotation), the SoW (Statement of Work) defines the roles, schedule and ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 26262 requirements applicable.
5.7 Counterfeit electronic components
Distributors / suppliers of electronic components shall provide evidence of genuine components prior
to supplying YAZAKI . Based on the receiving YAZAKI  manufacturing plant requirements, supplier must
submit minimum evidence, but not limited to, pictures of component packaging, packaging label and
component marking. The affected YAZAKI  manufacturing plant can verify the evidence provided with
the original component manufacturer (OCM (Original Component Manufacturer)) and all related costs (warranty field cost, revalidation, etc.)
will be charged in case any deficiency is detected.
Distributors / suppliers are obliged to demonstrate capable component management to avoid any
infiltration of counterfeit components at any time.
6 Production Requirements
While the production operations ultimately determine the quality of product, ensuring consistent
quality also depends on the capability of supporting processes. The processes described in this section
do not directly determine or improve product quality, but failure of these processes has the potential to
adversely affect product quality.
6.1 Modified Parts
For YAZAKI -nominated (design) parts, no modifications will be accepted without YAZAKI ’s written
approval. This applies to all modifications suggested or requested by supplier, YAZAKI  and OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer). For non-
YAZAKI  nominated parts, supplier shall inform YAZAKI  in writing according to the Supplier  Initiated

6.1.1 Change Categories
A modification may be due to any of the following which could affect fit, form or function:
A. Part modifications:
• Dimensions
• Raw material
• Technical specification (Performance / Test method / Handling Manuals)
B. Change of supplier or site (Material or service)
C. Process change:
• New tool
• Tool modification
• Process modification
• New process / technology
D. Plant change:
• Production / Tool transfer to a different plant
• Pick-up location change
For any above modification affecting the material of supplied components, a new MDS (Material Data Sheet) shall be
submitted to YAZAKI  via IMDS (International Material Data System) system and samples shall be sent by the supplier to PTC (Porto Technical Centre) testing Centre for
SoC (Substances of Concern) testing free of charge or provide a SoC (Substances of Concern) test report. See also 4.6.
The supplier is responsible for any modification (independent from originator of the change) affecting
the product they supply.
6.1.2 Change Notification across the Supply Chain
YAZAKI  Europe must also be informed in advance with submission of a SICR (Supplier  Initiated Change Request) in the YAZAKI  Supplier 
Portal (EmpowerQLM) when products / parts manufactured by suppliers’ subcontractors and when a modification (see
6.1.1) is proposed in response to a subcontractor request or any OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) request via sub-tiers.

6.1.3 Process Steps
A. Submission of SICR (Supplier  Initiated Change Request) form, duly filled out, at least 90 days prior to implementation date on

modification. See also specific info at the YAZAKI  Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM).
B. SICR (Supplier  Initiated Change Request) info will be analyzed upon receipt. Depending on the modification type, additional
samples might be required at YAZAKI  Europe Pilot plant for functional testing (see 4.3) and
at PTC (Porto Technical Centre) Testing Centre for SoC (Substances of Concern) tests. Alternatively, to the submission of samples for the SoC (Substances of Concern)
test, supplier shall provide a SoC (Substances of Concern) test report (see 4.6). Please contact the YAZAKI  SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer).
C. Provision of a change implementation schedule to affected YAZAKI  manufacturing plants.
D. Provision of evidence about security stock level to ensure parts delivery during any change
related production down time. In the event of irreversible modifications, the security stock
must be validated together with affected YAZAKI  manufacturing plants prior to
implementation of the modification, and records kept and made available to YAZAKI (if
required).
E. Identification of new / changed part level. Whenever a change occurred packaging of the
next three consecutive deliveries to YAZAKI  manufacturing plants must be identified with
an orange or otherwise agreed label with information, the SICR (Supplier  Initiated Change Request) ID, SICR (Supplier  Initiated Change Request) description, YPN (Yazaki Part Number)
and SPN (Supplier  Part Number).
6.2 Annual Product  Verification
Verification testing shall be performed annually to ensure the intended design requirements are
maintained. All applicable documents shall be updated to reflect product performance throughout
production, including updates to the original PPAP (or equivalent) submission and dimensional annual
layout. All appropriate design verification documentation must be made available within 48 hours upon
YAZAKI ’s request.
This Annual Requalification shall be agreed with AQSE for every specific project by mentioning it in the
Control Plan and needs to be linked also with OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) specific requirements.
6.3 Deviations / Concessions
Deviations / Concessions will only be considered for a specific quantity of parts / products or a specific
time frame and must be documented and signed by a YAZAKI  Design Engineer and YAZAKI  SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer)
6.3.1 Deviation
A Deviation is a written request from a supplier to knowingly manufacture parts/products which in some
way, do not conform exactly to specification i.e. supplier cannot produce parts according to specification
and requests YAZAKI  for deviation approval.
6.3.2 Concession
A concession is the written request from a supplier to ask YAZAKI  to accept and use parts already made
/ in transit, which do not conform to specification, and which the supplier has only become aware of
after manufacture.

6.3.3 Handling of Deviations / Concessions
Deviations / concession shall be communicated by using the CDAR (Component Deviation Approval Request) form (Component Deviation Approval
Request). The CDAR (Component Deviation Approval Request) form is available at the YAZAKI  Europe Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM). YAZAKI ’s decision on a
deviation / concession will always be given in writing. Representative samples should be submitted with
the CDAR (Component Deviation Approval Request) form to the responsible SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) who will further coordinate with related Engineering Department
and SQA (Supplier  Quality Assurance Engineer) of the affected YAZAKI  manufacturing plant. If YAZAKI  accepts the deviations / concessions,
each delivery must be identified with a label “Deviation / Concession ‘X’”.
6.4 Product  Traceability
Products supplied to YAZAKI  shall be traceable up to batch production or up to a maximum of 8 hours
of production, whichever is smaller. Supplier  shall ensure that the traceability plan maintains its integrity
all the way back to each production step and inspection lot across the entire supply chain.
The traceability plan must be agreed with YAZAKI  on the supplier’s initiative and installed in enough time
before PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) submission. YAZAKI  specific requirements for traceability must be taken into
consideration.
6.5 First In First Out inventory control
Suppliers are responsible to have inventory control systems that positively identify and control obsolete
material to prevent inadvertent shipment to the YAZAKI . Where feasible, suppliers shall maintain First
In First Out (FIFO) inventory management practice. The system for FIFO control must ensure controls
extend to rework/repair, test activity and off-site (sub-contract) processes.
6.6 Sub-supplier Management
YAZAKI  suppliers are responsible for the development of their sub-suppliers. They shall have the
necessary process, competence and resources to manage their sub-suppliers (including directed-buy
suppliers and outsourced processes) and monitor their performance. They shall also ensure that the
sub-suppliers comply with all the requirements contained in this Manual.
An intent to change a sub-supplier shall be communicated well in advance to YAZAKI . The change of a
sub-supplier can only be implemented upon prior approval by YAZAKI . See section 6.1.2 – Change
Notification across the Supply Chain. Subsequently, Production Part Approval Process (PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process)) shall
be performed.
YAZAKI  reserves the right to participate in audits and assessments of sub-suppliers regarding quality
management systems, processes, products etc. jointly with the YAZAKI  supplier, YAZAKI  ’s customers or
a third party assigned by YAZAKI . Advance notice will be given. YAZAKI  participation in a sub-supplier
audit does not absolve the YAZAKI  supplier from their responsibility to properly monitor and develop
the sub-supplier

7 Performance Measurements and Corrective Actions
YAZAKI  recognizes that the performance of the supply base has a direct and immediate impact on
organizational performance. In response to this, YAZAKI  has developed a system for the measurement
and evaluation of supplier performance. The indicators resulting from this process are compiled every
month and are reviewed and evaluated at all levels of the YAZAKI  organization. These measurements
are shared by Category SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer), for HIS (High Impact Supplier ) review.
7.1 Non-conforming material and Corrective action response
It is in the interest of both YAZAKI  and the supplier, to identify and address non-conforming parts as
quickly as possible. Suppliers shall take all necessary actions to respond to non-conforming product that
reach a YAZAKI  facility (production site, warehouse, etc.). Every effort is taken to investigate and
document non-conformances and to notify the supplier immediately.
All costs (sorting, handling, shipping, rework and inspection report costs) associated with addressing a
non-conformance will be the supplier’s responsibility. These costs may include any secondary costs
incurred by YAZAKI  resulting from a non-conformance, such as the costs associated with tear down,
reassembly, re-testing, and logistics support.
7.1.1 Treatment of Complaints / Rejections
The supplier is responsible for the quality of parts/products delivered at all times, starting from
nomination of the supplier until end of project/product lifetime, EOP + 15 years (or other defined on
SoW (Statement of Work)). Supplier  is also responsible for delivery of the correct parts / products, to the correct YAZAKI 
Europe location. The supplier’s responsibility is not only for his individual part, but also for any concerns
/ rejections / recalls etc. with YAZAKI  products/ parts which have been produced using supplier’s defect
/ suspect product/parts and are related to those defect / suspect product /parts. Whenever a quality
concern has occurred, the next three deliveries, with conformance confirmed, must be identified with
an extra green label.
7.1.2 Treatment of Quality & Logistic Complaints / Rejections
The supplier shall apply the eight disciplines (8D) root cause analysis problem solving methodology and
have evidence of official training on problem solving techniques.
EA-PU-xx-M-740_New, 17/MAR/2022 20 of 26 YAZAKI  Europe Group
2022 (C) COPYRIGHT BY YAZAKI  EUROPE LTD. ANY REPRODUCTION OR DISCLOSURE IS (Initial Sample) PROHIBITED WITHOUT PRIOR WRITTEN CONSENT OF YAZAKI

The supplier must provide to YAZAKI  facilities an 8D report which must be in the English language, and
which upon closure, clearly defines and verifies corrective actions implemented to eliminate the root
cause.
This process must be carried by the supplier using the web-based YAZAKI  Global Quality Reporting
System for Components (GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components)) (https://gpdb.yazaki-europe.com/sm_apps/). User Manuals are
posted in the portal, if necessary, further guidance / advice on the correct use of this system can be
obtained from the SQA (Supplier  Quality Assurance Engineer) and/or SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer).
7.1.3 Responsiveness / Pro-Activeness
Suppliers are selected because of their competence, qualification and particular commodity experience
in an automotive environment. This includes that suppliers must be responsive and proactive for the
entire life of the product.
Design and Development phase:
Supplier  is responsible to mention risks, advantages and disadvantages related to possible tools during
RFQ (Request for Quotation) negotations related to their investment proposals.
Suppliers must assist YAZAKI  project teams to find the best technical solutions at competitive prices,
without compromising the required level of quality.
Production phase:
Suppliers must be committed to provide the necessary resources to resolve any concerns as top priority.
Post-production phase:
Suppliers must be committed to support and take responsibility for any concerns occurring after
production phase i.e. field claims, warranty concerns.
7.1.4 Immediate Corrective Action
The supplier shall name a ´Champion´, who is the responsible contact person, for each supplier
manufacturing location. When YAZAKI  and associated companies receive products from more than one
supplier manufacturing location, the supplier shall name a European coordinator to assist
communication.
Production flow interruption: In the event of non-conformities, the supplier must provide corrective
actions necessary to ensure YAZAKI  production without interruption. These actions may include sorting,
rework, containment, immediate replacement of defectives, and identification of `OK` parts / materials,
and the presence of the supplier’s personnel in the YAZAKI  facilities affected, at supplier´s cost. Suppliers
must respond within 24 hours (maximum) when notified of a concern.
Agreed containment action may include visits of specific supplier personnel to YAZAKI  facilities to review
/ analyze the concerns. This is in addition to supplier personnel who may be carrying out sort / rework
activities, as referred to above.
Suppliers shall provide YAZAKI  with an initial 8D root cause analysis report using the GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components) portal,
identifying containment actions (3D) within 24 hours. The appropriate YAZAKI  SQA (Supplier  Quality Assurance Engineer) personnel
responsible for handling the concern must review and approve the proposed supplier actions.

7.1.5 Permanent Corrective Action
Suppliers must provide YAZAKI  with 8D root cause analysis report within 10 working days with an 8D
report detailing complete corrective action.
A corrective action-timing plan (in conjunction with 7.1.4 above), must be submitted to the appropriate
SQA (Supplier  Quality Assurance Engineer) personnel, who must approve the proposed plan / actions.
7.1.6 Customer Line Returns and Warranty Returns to YAZAKI 
If supplier responsibility is identified, customer line returns and warranty returns will be managed as
quality incidents and reported in the GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components) portal. The same process applies as explained in section
7.1.1. For warranty/field claims, supplier is still responsible for their components even project is end of
life, EOP +15 years (pr other period mention on SoW (Statement of Work)).
7.1.7 Repetitive Problems
A repetitive problem indicates that the corrective actions according to 8D report were not effective or
not implemented. Moreover, the effectiveness of the corrective action was not verified, as required by
the 8D process.
In the case of repetitive problems, YAZAKI  may request supplier’s senior management to visit the YAZAKI 
Europe plant to propose and commit to a complete business action plan.
Supplier  shall provide 100% inspection and identification of purchased parts /products until the problem
is eliminated (Controlled Shipping), and if requested by YAZAKI , must agree to a process audit at the
relevant supplier facility.
7.1.8 Cost of Non-Quality
In the case of quality and supply concerns caused by suppliers and accepted as justified by the supplier,
all direct and indirect costs incurred at YAZAKI  in particular for exceeding delivery dates, labor, materials,
additional freight, lack of output, plus any other associated costs will be fully charged back to the
delinquent supplier. This will be based upon the data collected via the GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components) portal (Cost Agreement)
related to the length / magnitude of the concern /rejection.
7.2 Quality Objectives - Quality Improvement Plan
Suppliers are expected to use the lessons learned from each incident to improve production process,
product design, or underlying business systems. The goal is to eliminate the possibility of similar
incidents, not only by making procedural and process adjustments on the manufacturing floor, but by
removing the environment that allowed the issue to surface. Lasting improvement requires correcting
the systems and strategies that support the production process.
In addition to responding to identified non-conformances, suppliers should use statistical data to
continually evaluate and refine their processes. This evaluation should include analysis of quality out of
control indications, high PPM (Parts Per Million), scrap, downtime, and warranty failures. The clear objective of this analysis
must be reduction of variation with the finished product. The supplier shall have on-going, active
improvement projects that target two or three of the largest problem areas and be able to demonstrate
a positive trend in reducing incidents and repeat occurrences.

7.2.1 Zero Defects Philosophy
All suppliers are expected to drive Zero Defects Philosophy throughout their supply chain, aiming to
deliver defect free material at the required time. The ultimate quality target can only be zero PPM (Parts Per Million).
For suppliers defined as high impact, individual PPM (Parts Per Million) Targets per project will be defined and specified,
considering the product and technology as well as given customer requirements, in project specific
documentation.
The quality objective on parts/products used on new projects i.e. projects in ramp-up prior to volume
production, will be negotiated between SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) / supplier at the relevant time, but the ultimate target /
objective will still be defect free deliveries (zero PPM (Parts Per Million)).
7.2.2 Supplier  Performance Evaluation / Supplier  Score Card
Supplier  Quality & Logistic Performance is measured against following KPI (Key Performance Indicator)´s:
1. PPM (Parts Per Million) Performance
2. Rejection Performance - Rejections per million (RPM)
3. 3D Reactivity Performance
4. 8D Reactivity Performance
5. Documentation Performance
6. Delivery Performance
7. Number of Rejections
8. Line-stop Performance
9. 3D Reactivity Performance of Customer Concern
Downgrading criteria: Subcategory fail (D level). The overall status (A, B, C, D level) is the sum of all KPI (Key Performance Indicator)
scores and considering the downgrading:
SCORE LEVEL STATUS
85 ≤ Score ≤ 100 A Preferred
67 ≤ Score < 85 B Acceptable
50 ≤ Score < 67 C Probationary
0 ≤ Score < 50 D Unacceptable
For detailed information, refer to the YAZAKI  Europe Limited Supplier  Score Card Manual stored at the
YAZAKI  Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM).
7.2.3 Supplier  Development / Quality Improvement Plan
The supplier quality performance is monitored and is the base for deploying development activities to
improve Quality, Cost, Delivery and Environmental objectives.
For suppliers defined as high impact and / or with a decreasing quality performance trend are expected
to deliver a comprehensive Supplier  Quality Improvement Plan (SQIP (Supplier  Quality Improvement Plan)) for continuous improvement of
their system, organization, etc., showing how Quality, Cost, Delivery and Environmental objectives are
to be achieved.

Individual Quality Commitments with quality objectives are set-up by the SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) and agreed with the
Supplier  on a yearly basis, at a minimum.
7.3 Supplier  Audits
Audits at supplier premises may be performed for following reasons:
• New supplier
• New supplier location
• New / additional business
• New process
• During APQP (Advanced Product  Quality Planning), before and or after PPAP (Production Part Approval Process)/Product  approval
• Poor performance
• After a major incident
• Other…
The supplier will be notified in advance in due time in comparison to the audit reason by the YAZAKI 
Auditor / SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) about any planned audit activity. The supplier is responsible to be well prepared for the
audit including submission of the self-assessment in advance in order to assure the audit can be
conducted in a proper way. The Audit format applied is the VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) 6.3 standard but can also be any other
Customer specific assessment questionnaire.
YAZAKI  reserves the right to charge the supplier for the expenses incurred if an unacceptable audit score
level or preparation is detected during the on-site audit.
The related costs will be clearly communicated through YAZAKI  Purchasing.
7.4 Continuous Improvement
Suppliers to YAZAKI  are expected to drive continuous improvement activities throughout the whole
organization.
Besides the basic standards of high level housekeeping / 5S, Visual Management, Mistake Proofing tools
(Poka-Yoke) and good problem solving methods, it is also recommended to implement and maintain a
Lean Management philosophy and principles using tools such as Value Stream Mapping, Single Minute
Exchange of Die (SMED), Overall Equipment Effectiveness (OEE), Kanban, Standardized Work, Total
Productive Maintenance (TPM) etc. The respective SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) will verify the level of implementation during
on-site visits / audits.
7.5 Supplier  Performance Deviation Management - Escalation process
SPDM (Supplier  Performance Deviation Management) with level of escalation is communicated through a notification letter that initiates and invites
appropriate YAZAKI  and supplier representatives with a formal agenda and appropriate meeting place
and time to develop an improvement plan that will then be followed until the corrective actions are
implemented and followed until the action is satisfactory.
SPDM (Supplier  Performance Deviation Management) De-escalation letter is sent to supplier when deviating performance is corrected.
More detailed information can be found on https://www.yazaki-europe.com/supplier - Supplier  Private
area – Reference Document EA-PU-xx-P-632 Supplier  Performance Deviation Management.
SPDM (Supplier  Performance Deviation Management) process is applicable to both Direct & Indirect Material suppliers.

1. Scope
The requirements defined in this Supplier  Quality Manual apply to all suppliers of safe and marketable goods
and services, in particular production parts and materials to Plants and BU (Business Unit) customer locations within the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA)
EMEA (Europe Middle East Africa).
The Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Supplier  Quality Manual is valid for the supply of production materials, software and Aftermarket
products.
It is also valid for services that affect customer requirements such as sub-assembly, sequencing, sorting,
rework, and calibration services.
It applies to all suppliers along the supply chain providing products to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA). It is also applicable for customer
directed suppliers (directed buy).
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) suppliers are expected to extend the requirements of Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Supplier  Quality Manual to their own
suppliers.
This Quality Manual also applies to intra-Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) business to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA).
2. Purpose
The purpose of the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) EMEA (Europe Middle East Africa)’s Supplier  Quality Manual is to clearly define the quality system procedures
and disciplines to ensure and maintain a successful and professional relationship between Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Purchasing
and suppliers.
These expectations are Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) specific and are based upon and in addition to the latest editions of the following
International and Global Management Standards: ISO9001, IATF16949, ISO14001, ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 45001, Core Quality
Tools (APQP (Advanced Product  Quality Planning), PPAP (Production Part Approval Process), FMEA (Failure Mode and Effects Analysis), SPC and MSA), OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer)/Customer Specific Requirements as well as applicable European
Union environment legislation, and any applicable local legal requirements.
Requirements listed in this Manual do not constitute a restriction or exception to any stated regulations or
legal requirements.
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) EMEA (Europe Middle East Africa) depends on the quality, cost, delivery and environment provided by our suppliers. We are
committed to developing strong supplier partnerships through mutual trust and commitment.
3. Management Systems Requirements
3.1 Quality / Environmental / Health & Safety Management System
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) EMEA (Europe Middle East Africa) Purchase Policy is wherever possible to only purchase goods & services from suppliers that hold
third party certification for their Quality, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety Management
Systems. Ultimately, all suppliers will be required to hold third-party certification to latest editions of IATF
16949, ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 14001 and ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 45001.
In the case of a certificate suspension decision from the supplier’s IATF recognized Certification body, Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA)
shall be informed by the supplier within 30 days of the decision. If no recertification is planned, the supplier
shall inform Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA), at least 3 months prior to the expiration date.
All suppliers of Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) shall be third party registered to ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 9001 (latest edition) by an accredited third-party
certification body. Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) EMEA (Europe Middle East Africa) reserves the right, whenever deemed necessary, to carry out its own
assessments on suppliers and / or their subcontractors (by agreement with the supplier).

Page 6 of 27
IATF 16949 certificates are considered as valid only if provided by an IATF recognized certification body. Non-
compliant suppliers shall provide a timing/transition plan to move as soon as possible to an approved IATF
Certification Body - official list at the IATF site.
3.1.1 Certificate Management – Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM)
Suppliers are required to manage their certificates of all active sites (Manufacturing locations, Sales offices &
Logistic/ Warehouses/ Distribution Centres) in the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM). Latest versions of Management
System certificates shall be uploaded in this portal, as a minimum ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 9001, IATF 16949, ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 14001 and ISO (International Organization for Standardization)
45001 certificates, other certificates are optional. Automatic system messaging to supplier users is activated
once certificate expiry dates are entered. For further details refer to the ´ Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) EMEA (Europe Middle East Africa) Certificate Manual´
posted at the Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM)
3.2 Regulatory and Statutory Compliance
The supplier shall apply the legal requirements of the production location and of the country of use (if named
by Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA)) during the APQP (Advanced Product  Quality Planning) phase to all products, processes or services (internal and external). This process
shall be completed at the latest by PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) submission.
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) suppliers shall adhere to and pass down all applicable statutory and regulatory requirements to their
suppliers in the entire supply chain.
3.3 Environmental Protection
The supplier shall take responsibility to ensure compliance to all relevant environmental legislation, both
applicable to the regions where goods are produced and/or sold or services are performed, as well as any
additional specific requirements from customers. When necessary, investigations within the supply chain shall
be done to assure all requirements are communicated effectively and complied with.
Effective environmental management, which ensures compliance with the respective applicable environmental
regulations and improves continuously and efficiently the environmental conditions of the supplier, is an
essential contribution towards supply security.
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) is committed to the protection of the environment. All Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) plants are ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 14001 certified. We
therefore expect our suppliers to show voluntary commitment to environmental protection by implementing
an environmental management system.
Upon request, suppliers shall provide recycling and disposal concepts appropriate for their products and
related quantities. Additional data such as water consumption and wastewater, energy consumption and
emissions (CO , VOC) may be requested for life cycle assessment of Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) products.
2
All products and materials (including packaging thereof) delivered to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) shall be conform with below
regulatory requirements:
• ELV (End of Life Vehicle), Directive 2000/53/EC
• REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals), Regulation (EC) No. 1907/2006
• RoHS (Restriction of Hazardous Substances), Directive 2011/65/EU
• CLP (Classification, Labeling and Packaging), Regulation (EC) No. 1272/2008
• Biocidal Products, Regulation (EU) No. 528/2012
• Packaging and Packaging Waste, Directive 94/62/EC
• Ozone Depletion Substances, Regulation (EC) No. 1005/2009
• POP (Persistent Organic Pollutants), Regulation (EU) No. 2019/1021

IMDS (International Material Data System) - International Material Data System, see http://www.mdsystem.com
In order to collect the necessary material data information, Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) requires that suppliers report it through the
International Material Data System directly.
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) IMDS (International Material Data System) Company ID# is 223417. Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA)’s acceptance criteria are based on IMDS (International Material Data System) recommendations.
Supplier  must be aware of updates to the GADSL and ensure that information submitted is correct and comply
with the recommendations of the IMDS (International Material Data System) system.
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) can request clarifications and corrections to previously submitted and accepted IMDS (International Material Data System) data.
EU REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals) Regulation (EC) No. 1907/2006
The Supplier  must fulfill all obligations due to Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of
Chemicals. This includes communication obligations of SVHC (Substances of Very High Concern) in articles, even for spare parts and packaging.
Suppliers located outside the European Union have to name an Only Representative (OR) if they deliver
products defined as ´substances´ or ´mixtures into the area of validity of the REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals) regulation. The OR ensures
that the REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals) obligations are met. The OR’s name has to be notified to the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA).
EU REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals) SVHC (Substances of Very High Concern)
All substances added to the Candidate List and present in products above 0.1% w/w must be notified to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA).
When the Candidate List is updated, and new Substances of Very High Concern (SVHC (Substances of Very High Concern)) are added then the
obligation for suppliers to inform their customers becomes immediately effective.
The supplier is requested not to use SVHC (Substances of Very High Concern) in articles and mixtures delivered to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA).
EU REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals) Annex XIV (Authorization List)
Supplier  shall not use any substance included in this list.
EU REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals) Annex XVII (Restriction List)
Supplier  shall only use substances from the list if it complies with the restrictions.

Safety Data Sheet (SDS (Safety Data Sheet))
For chemical products and raw materials suppliers are required to send an updated SDS (Safety Data Sheet) to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) in English
language and in the local language of the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) affiliates using these products (except for Turkish affiliates).
The SDS (Safety Data Sheet) must be in accordance with REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals) and CLP (Classification, Labeling and Packaging) legislation requirements.
In case suppliers deliver chemical products and raw materials to any Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) affiliate located in Turkey, the SDS (Safety Data Sheet)
must be submitted in Turkish language and comply with KKDIK (Kimyasalların, Kaydı, Değerlendirilmesi, İzni ve Kısıtlanması (i.e., Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals)) and SEA legislation requirements.
3.4 Corporate Social Responsibility and Business Partner’s Code of Conduct
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) follows Corporate Social Responsibility activities based on the global Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Group Corporate Social
Responsibility Policy and Strategy. Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) specifies detailed requirements towards its suppliers in the document
` Business Partner’s Code of Conduct´. The whole set of documents is available on Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA)’s homepage, section
`Suppliers - Purchasing Documents`.
To improve transparency on sustainability on our supply chain, eligible suppliers identified by Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) must
provide the necessary information during onboarding or evaluation processes, which may include answering
sustainability questionnaires or similar assessments when requested. Suppliers are required to cooperate and
share relevant details upon request.
3.5 Product  Safety
Product  safety and product liability are particularly significant for companies in the automotive industry. The
supplier has producer responsibility (product liability) for their parts and processes, including parts or
processes from sub-suppliers, which Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) purchases to build their final products. Therefore, in order to
prevent product liability risks, it is the responsibility of the supplier to do everything in their power, in terms
of organization and technical matters, to guarantee the product safety.
The supplier shall have a documented process for the management of “product safety” related products and
manufacturing processes.
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) requires their suppliers to designate a Product  Safety Representative (PSCR (Product Safety & Conformity Representative)) to be in charge of all related
tasks described in IATF 16949 section 4.4.1.2.
Furthermore, the supplier shall apply these requirements to their supply chain.
Suppliers of safety critical components will be required to participate in Safety Management Audits.
3.6 Cybersecurity
Supplier  must be able to demonstrate an Information Security Program which is formal, supported and
maintained. This includes, but is not limited to:
• Information Security policies and controls
• Security Incident Response and Communication Plan
• Security Awareness Program which includes simulations and user training
• Identification and Management of security risks
Evidence of compliance may include an Information Security Certification (e.g., ISO27001, TISAX, SOC (Substances of Concern) 1 or 2)
from an external auditing body or a security assessment initiated by Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) which may be performed onsite or
remote.
EA-QM-xx-M-740, Rev New, 11/12/2024

4. New Parts/Products
For each new part / product or first time buy for Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA), the supplier must submit initial samples (IS (Initial Sample)) with a
complete report, handling manuals and other supporting documents in accordance with requirements of IATF
16949, related AIAG (Automotive Industry Action Group) / VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) manuals APQP (Advanced Product  Quality Planning) & PPAP (latest edition) and any other OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer)/Customer specific
requirements specified during contract release free of charge. The report must contain Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) part number,
technical engineering level and clear and complete supplier identification data. PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) packages must be
complete, accurate and up to date for the products / parts in question always. Samples shall be provided free
of charge to PTC (Porto Technical Centre) Testing Centre for SoC (Substances of Concern) testing, to the relevant Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) manufacturing plant for assembly trials,
and to the SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) upon request (see 4.6).
The suppliers of proprietary or other products /parts must provide documented evidence of formal OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) /
customer approval of product validation, which clearly demonstrates conformance to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) requirements and
OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer)/customer requirements, including a signed PSW (Part Submission Warrant). Where PSW (Part Submission Warrant)’s must be updated on a regular basis,
according to OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) requirements e.g. annual lay-outs, suppliers will be notified by SDDC (Supplier  Development Documentation Center) to submit updated
PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) documentation free of charge. Initial Samples must be sent as scheduled and always before the start of
volume production. Samples must be identified with “Initial Sample” labels and accompanied by appropriate
documentation. Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Purchasing, SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) or SDDC (Supplier  Development Documentation Center) may define samples delivery to the relevant Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) `Pilot
Plant`.
Unless otherwise specified by Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA), the submission of PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) shall be according AIAG (Automotive Industry Action Group) Level 3 or VDA2 with all
applicable deliverables submitted.
4.1 Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Designed Products
For all Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) designed products / parts and upon request of Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA), APQP (Advanced Product  Quality Planning) or VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) MLA (Maturity Level Assurance (acc. to VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association))))/RGA methodology, must
be applied by the supplier and follow upped by ASQE (Advanced Supplier  Quality Engineer).
Project Management must be tracked via the Integrated Supplier  Quality Management System. Supplier  shall
register to Integrated Supplier  Quality Management System if required. In that case, Integrated Supplier 
Quality Management System -membership fee, if applicable, is at the cost of the supplier. Projects will be
kicked off by the SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) who specifies APQP (Advanced Product  Quality Planning) and PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) scope.
Additionally, a Process Sign Off (including VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) 6.3 Process Audit, R@R, Capacity Check) must be carried out by
the SQE (or by supplier) before initial sample submission, in order to validate the process and product in
accordance with IATF 16949 and any other OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) / Customer specific requirement. See also Section 4.2.
4.2 Customer Specific Requirements
Supplier  is responsible to follow and implement latest revision of Customer Specific Requirement, available
on https://www.iatfglobaloversight.org/oem-requirements/customer-specific-requirements/.
General customer specific requirements included in this Manual shall be implemented.
Additional customer specific requirements issued by Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) customers will be communicated on a project
basis. Their application will be subject to an agreement between Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) and the supplier.

4.3 Reasons for Initial Samples
The PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) Approval Process is required if any of the following changes apply at the supplier or sub-supplier:
• if a product is ordered for the first time
• after the supplier has changed a subcontractor
• for all affected characteristics after any product modification
• for all affected characteristics following a drawing index modification
• following an interruption in delivery after a stop shipment (business on hold)
• following an interruption in delivery of more than one year
• following an interruption in production of more than one year
• if production procedures/processes have been changed
• following the introduction of new/modified molding equipment (e.g. stamping, rolling, pressing,
forging, molding equipment, in the case of several dies/molds and/or multiple dies/molds, for each
cavity/cluster)
• following any type of relocation of PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process)- approved production or the use of new or relocated
machinery and/or operating materials
• after use of alternative materials and design changes in product appearance attributes
• change in test/inspection method or new technique (no effect on acceptance criteria). For change
in test method, supplier should have evidence that the new method provides results equivalent to
or better than the old (previous) method
• Production following upgrade, refurbishment, rearrangement of existing tooling or equipment, if
requested by Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA)
• Re-qualification is not successful
Exceptions to approach and scope are only permissible in agreement with Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA), for example in the following
cases:
• interruption in delivery or production of more than one year
• small production batches, after-sales service parts
• standard and catalogue parts
Initial and SoC (Substances of Concern)-samples (see 4.6) must follow the requirements with first submission to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA).
Documents, records, and initial sample parts may only be submitted if all specifications are fulfilled. In case of
deviations, the supplier shall first obtain written permission from Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) using the CDAR (Component Deviation Approval Request) form (Component
Deviation Approval Request). The CDAR (Component Deviation Approval Request) form is available at the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM) and attach it to the
submitted documentation. Initial samples with deviations that have no deviation approval will not be
processed by Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA).
The following shall be submitted along with the deviation request, if CDAR (Component Deviation Approval Request) is approved for a limited quantity
or time period:
• 8D report
• An action plan to return to planned serial conditions
• Risk Assessment
• The planned point of time when normal production can be resumed
EA-QM-xx-M-740, Rev New, 11/12/2024

4.4 Special Characteristics
Special Characteristics are specified by Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA)/OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) and documented on the drawings and/or specifications.
They are to be identified as well, from the risk analysis of the supplier, e.g. from the product and/or process
FMEA (Failure Mode and Effects Analysis), based on the supplier’s experience and knowledge.
Deviations in these characteristics can seriously affect product safety, product lifetime, assembly capability,
product functionality, quality and can violate official or legal regulations.
The supplier shall agree to conduct the machine capability study and process capability study according to one
of the automotive standards VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) Volume 2, VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) Volume 4 or AIAG (Automotive Industry Action Group) book SPC.
If no other requirements are specified on drawings or OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) CSR (Customer Specific Requirements), supplier shall use the following explanation
according to VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) or alternative definition in AIAG (Automotive Industry Action Group):
SC (Significant/Special Characteristic) Characteristics
• Machine capability/short-term process capability Cm/Cmk >1.67
• Preliminary process capability Pp/Ppk >1.67
• Process capability/long-term process capability Cp/Cpk >1.33
CC (Critical Characteristics, feature, dimension, or drawing note that may affect compliance with legal requirements or product safety) Characteristics
• Machine capability/short-term process capability Cm/Cmk >2
• Preliminary process capability Pp/Ppk >2
• Process capability/long-term process capability Cp/Cpk >1.67
If capability cannot be demonstrated, poka-yoke systems must be applied, or 100% inspection must be
implemented.
4.5 IMDS (International Material Data System)
For each new part an MDS (Material Data Sheet) according to IMDS (International Material Data System) recommendations must be submitted to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) via IMDS (International Material Data System) system
and the information of MDS (Material Data Sheet) ID-number must be stated in the PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) documentation. For all products / parts
supplied, the supplier must automatically provide any changes to MDS (Material Data Sheet).

4.7 Capacity Verification (Run at Rate)
A Run at Rate (R@R) is a performance driven trial run under serial production conditions, this can be one-day
production or an agreed deviating time period, by Advance Supplier  Quality Engineer.
The purpose of R@R is to demonstrate that Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) requirements for supplier capacity are met, to provide
evidence that the supplier can produce the required volumes to specification with existing capacity and to
identify potential process weaknesses.
Potential reasons for performing R@R:
• new product/ new supplier
• changes in product, process or equipment
• capacity increase

Unless otherwise agreed, the R@R shall be applied to all production material supplied to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA). The R@R Tool
specified by Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) shall be used.
Catalogue parts are excluded from this R@R requirement. In case of any exception from performing a R@R,
supplier capacity for the respective parts shall then be assured and documented with a separate capacity
commitment signed by the supplier.
The R@R shall be conducted either on all process steps or on individual bottleneck/critical process steps.
When limited to individual process steps, the reason(s) shall be documented.
R@R result shall be provided using the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) R@R Verification Form signed by the Supplier .
The signed form R@R Verification is required for PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) documentation.
4.8 CQI/Qualification of Special Processes
The AIAG (Automotive Industry Action Group) is publisher of the CQI guidelines (Continuous Quality
Improvement). CQI formats are available at http://www.aiag.org/.
For suppliers and sub-suppliers dealing with special processes according to AIAG, relevant CQI-guidelines shall
be considered. For such processes yearly self-assessment shall be carried out in the whole supply chain.
If the result shows findings of the type “Need for Immediate Action” or “Fail Findings”, the supplier shall inform
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) immediately and provide an action plan.
Upon Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) request copies of the performed special process assessment cover sheet need to be provided
within one day.
4.9 Customer’s Property
All tools for manufacturing, testing or inspection equipment belonging to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) or customers of Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) shall
be permanently marked to clearly show that they are property of Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) or of the customer of Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA). These
tools shall only be used for Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) products, unless an authorization in writing exists.
Tools cannot be relocated to other manufacturing location or subcontracted to 3rd parties without prior
written approval from Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA).
4.10 Packaging
Material packaging is part of the PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) and as such to be agreed and validated during project phase, prior
to PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) approval. Packaging material must comply with REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals) regulation, Packaging directive, customer
and local requirements. The supplier must submit a declaration as evidence of compliance. A `Packaging
Specification` template is available at the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM). For further details see ` Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Supplier 
Logistics Manual´
4.11 Communication of Approval
SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) will notify supplier with a documented approval or rejection of the IS (Initial Sample) and PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) submission. In the event
of rejection, Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Purchasing will be notified for consideration in tool payments. Until Full Approval, Green
PPAP (Production Part Approval Process), complete tool payment to supplier will not be done.

4.12 Safe Launch
Safe Launch planning is designed to protect both Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) and the supplier during the initial phases of product
supply. A Safe Launch process shall be implemented to detect symptoms of potential issues in new processes
and to ensure that new launches are defect free. To accomplish this, a Safe Launch Plan shall be agreed during
the planning phase. During Safe Launch, an increased frequency of inspection and monitoring shall be
performed on designated and other agreed characteristics.
The supplier nominates an empowered interdisciplinary team with defined responsibilities to ensure the
conformity of the parts and to analyze and eliminate internal rejects in a timely manner.
In general, the Safe Launch phase starts with the PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) submission and extends until start of production
(SOP of the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) customer) + 90 days, unless otherwise specified by Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA). The program duration may also
be specified by a quantity of product.
Zero defect supplies during the entire Safe Launch phase and fulfillment of all agreed criteria qualify the
supplier for an exit out of the Safe Launch phase.
Any defect discovered during the Safe Launch Phase resets the event to “0” and the Safe Launch Phase is
restarted.
Filled in Safe Launch forms, inspection raw data and capability charts shall be submitted on agreed frequency
to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) by means of the information exchange platforms defined by Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA).
5. Electronic components
For suppliers who develop and/or produce, assemble or test electronic components (particularly
semiconductor devices, passive components and LED components) the additional, specific requirements
described in section 5 shall be applied
5.1 AECQ
Suppliers who develop and/or produce, assemble or test electronic components shall at a minimum fulfill the
respective qualification standard from the Automotive Electronics Council (AEC; e.g. AECQ 100; AECQ 101;
AECQ 200). Exceptions or deviations to above, shall be communicated to and agreed with Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA).
5.2 IPC Standards
IPC enables reliable, high-quality electronics by developing the trusted standards that drive the global
electronics industry's success. Implemented industry-wide, our standards simply communicate and clarify
expectations for everyone within the industry. IPC standards help ensure superior quality, reliability and
consistency in electronics manufacturing. (https://ipc.org/).
Consider the requirements of last issued IPC Tree to the comparable mode of component type (ex. PCB Panel,
Full Assembly PCB)
EA-QM-xx-M-740, Rev New, 11/12/2024

5.3 Robustness Validation
The supplier shall provide their approach to robustness validation in the development phase. In addition, the
procedure of robustness validation shall be made available to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) for review and approval. For further
information, refer to ZVEI – Handbook of Robustness Validation.
5.4 Mission Profile for Electronic Components
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) may issue a series of work documents to be considered by the supplier:
• Mission Profile
• Statement of Work (SOW) and/or
• Manufacturing Process items at customer (PCB Assembly, Displays, etc Technical Manufacturing Rules
and Conditions)
• Technical Cleanliness Requirements according VDA19
5.5 Software and Components with Embedded Software
Suppliers who develop or supply software or electronic components with integrated software shall
demonstrate the capability of their software development process according to Automotive SPICE or an
equivalent standard. Unless otherwise agreed, the software development capability level 3 needs to be
fulfilled according to the VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) Volume “Automotive SPICE Process Assessment Model” for processes which are
part of the “VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) process scope.
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) retains the right to carry out an assessment at the supplier’s location.
If the agreed software development process capability level cannot be achieved, the supplier shall provide an
action plan including an adequate time schedule to achieve the agreed software development process
capability level.”
5.6 Functional Safety
When safety-relevant electronics and/or software (product or services) are included in the scope of supply,
then supplier shall be “state-of-the-art” and comply with ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 26262.
Safety-relevant parts, their documentation and the drawings shall be marked as such so that they can be
clearly identified throughout the development phase and series production process.
On RFQ (Request for Quotation), the SoW (Statement of Work) defines the roles, schedule and ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 26262 requirements applicable.
5.7 Counterfeit Electronic Components
Distributors / suppliers of electronic components shall provide evidence of genuine components prior to
supplying Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA). Based on the receiving Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) manufacturing plant requirements, supplier must submit
minimum evidence, but not limited to, pictures of component packaging, packaging label and component
marking. The affected Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) manufacturing plant can verify the evidence provided with the original
component manufacturer (OCM (Original Component Manufacturer)) and all related costs (warranty field cost, revalidation, etc.) will be charged in
case any deficiency is detected.
Distributors / suppliers are obliged to demonstrate capable component management to avoid any infiltration
of counterfeit components at any time.
EA-QM-xx-M-740, Rev New, 11/12/2024

6. Production Requirements
While the production operations ultimately determine the quality of product, ensuring consistent quality also
depends on the capability of supporting processes. The processes described in this section do not directly
determine or improve product quality, but failure of these processes has the potential to adversely affect
product quality.
6.1 Modified Parts
For Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA)-nominated (design) parts, no modifications will be accepted without Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA)’s written approval. This
applies to all modifications suggested or requested by supplier, Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) and OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer). For non- Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) nominated
parts, supplier shall inform Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) in writing according to the Supplier  Initiated Change Request (SICR (Supplier  Initiated Change Request)) process
(see 6.1.3) with appropriate documentation about any modification, 90 days, prior to first shipment of parts.
In all cases a new PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) shall be submitted.
The effects of any change, including those changes caused by sub-suppliers, shall be assessed, verified and
validated to ensure compliance with Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) requirements prior to implementation. The evidence of risks
associated with the change shall be documented and assessed.
Any intended change, deviating from the latest PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) approval, shall be communicated to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) to allow
for a timely review and approval by Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA).
A “Change” refers to all situations referenced in AIAG (Automotive Industry Action Group) PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) Manual and/or VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) Volume 2, Trigger matrix of
Part history.
6.1.1 Change Categories
A modification may be due to any of the following which could affect fit, form or function:
A. Engineering Changes (fit, form or function, design, appearance, material)
B. Tool Replacement, Refurbishment of tooling, Tooling duplication
C. Tooling transfer/ Location change & Change in part processing
D. Material supplier source change
E. Discontinuation
F. Packaging change
G. Minor drawing change/handling manual change
H. Logistical change
For any above modification affecting the material of supplied components, a new MDS (Material Data Sheet) shall be submitted to
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) via IMDS (International Material Data System) system and samples shall be sent by the supplier to PTC (Porto Technical Centre) testing Centre for SoC (Substances of Concern) testing free of
charge or provide a SoC (Substances of Concern) test report. See also 4.6.
The supplier is responsible for any modification (independent from originator of the change) affecting the
product they supply.

6.1.2 Change Notification across the Supply Chain
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) must also be informed in advance with submission of a SICR (Supplier  Initiated Change Request) in the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM) when products
/ parts manufactured by suppliers’ subcontractors and when a modification (see 6.1.1) is proposed in response
to a subcontractor request or any OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) request via sub-tiers.
6.1.3 Process Steps
A. Submission of SICR (Supplier  Initiated Change Request) form, duly filled out, at least 90 days prior to implementation date on the
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM) including detailed information explaining the change / modification. See
also specific info at the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM).
B. SICR (Supplier  Initiated Change Request) info will be analyzed upon receipt. Depending on the modification type, additional samples
might be required at Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Pilot plant for functional testing (see 4.3) and at PTC (Porto Technical Centre) Testing Centre
for SoC (Substances of Concern) tests. Alternatively, to the submission of samples for the SoC (Substances of Concern) test, supplier shall provide a
SoC (Substances of Concern) test report (see 4.6). Please contact the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer).
C. Provision of a change implementation schedule to affected Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) manufacturing plants.
D. Provision of evidence about security stock level to ensure parts delivery during any change related
production down time. In the event of irreversible modifications, the security stock must be
validated together with affected Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) manufacturing plants prior to implementation of the
modification, and records kept and made available to Yazaki (if required).
E. Identification of new / changed part level. Whenever a change occurred packaging of the next
three consecutive deliveries to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) manufacturing plants must be identified with an orange or
otherwise agreed label with information, the SICR (Supplier  Initiated Change Request) ID, SICR (Supplier  Initiated Change Request) description, YPN (Yazaki Part Number) and SPN (Supplier  Part Number).
Note: If SICR (Supplier  Initiated Change Request) implementation is not done by the declared date of the supplier the change should be rendered
as obsolete unless agreed otherwise with the supplier
6.2 Requalification of Product  and Process
Unless otherwise agreed with OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) customer, product and process requalification testing shall be performed
according to the below-mentioned criteria to ensure intended design and quality requirements are
maintained.
All applicable documents shall be updated to reflect product and process performance throughout production,
including updates to the original PPAP (or equivalent) submission and Process self-assessment based on VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association))
2 or equivalent standard. Furthermore, all relevant documentation must be made available within 48 hours
upon Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA)’s request.
In line with the aforementioned statement, as an alternative to having a fixed frequency, the following criteria
can act as a trigger to activate requalification activities:
• Deterioration of Supplier  Quality performance resulting in SPDM (Supplier  Performance Deviation Management) monitoring
• Supplier  evaluated as High Impact Supplier  according to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Supplier  evaluation procedure
Note: For new supplier or new supplier location, a process self-assessment based on VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) 2 or equivalent
standard will be requested as part of the initial qualification
Note: For M2 parts (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) design parts and manufactured by external suppliers), Product  and process
requalification activities shall be agreed with ASQE (Advanced Supplier  Quality Engineer) for every specific project by mentioning it in the
Supplier  Control Plan and shall take into consideration OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer)-specific requirements.

6.3 Deviations / Concessions
Deviations / Concessions will only be considered for a specific quantity of parts / products or a specific time
frame and must be documented and signed by a Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Design Engineer and Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer).
6.3.1 Deviation
A Deviation is a written request from a supplier to knowingly manufacture parts/products which in some way,
do not conform exactly to specification i.e. supplier cannot produce parts according to specification and
requests Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) for deviation approval.
6.3.2 Concession
A concession is the written request from a supplier to ask Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) to accept and use parts already made / in
transit, which do not conform to specification, and which the supplier has only become aware of after
manufacture.
6.3.3 Handling of Deviations / Concessions
Deviations / concession shall be communicated by using the CDAR (Component Deviation Approval Request) form (Component Deviation Approval
Request). The CDAR (Component Deviation Approval Request) form is available at the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM). Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA)’s decision on a deviation / concession
will always be given in writing. Representative samples should be submitted with the CDAR (Component Deviation Approval Request) form to the
responsible SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) who will further coordinate with related Engineering Department and SQA (Supplier  Quality Assurance Engineer) of the affected
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) manufacturing plant. If Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) accepts the deviations / concessions, each delivery must be identified
with a label “Deviation / Concession ‘X’”.
6.4 Product  Traceability
Products supplied to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) shall be traceable up to batch production or up to a maximum of 8 hours of
production, whichever is smaller. Supplier  shall ensure that the traceability plan maintains its integrity all the
way back to each production step and inspection lot across the entire supply chain.
The traceability plan must be agreed with Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) on the supplier’s initiative and installed in enough time before
PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) submission. Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) specific requirements for traceability must be taken into consideration.
EA-QM-xx-M-740, Rev New, 11/12/2024

6.5 First In First Out Inventory Control
Suppliers are responsible to have inventory control systems that positively identify and control obsolete
material to prevent inadvertent shipment to the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA). Where feasible, suppliers shall maintain First In First
Out (FIFO) inventory management practice. The system for FIFO control must ensure controls extend to
rework/repair, test activity and off-site (sub-contract) processes.
6.6 Sub-supplier Management
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) suppliers are responsible for the development of their sub-suppliers. They shall have the necessary
process, competence and resources to manage their sub-suppliers (including directed-buy suppliers and
outsourced processes) and monitor their performance. They shall also ensure that the sub-suppliers comply
with all the requirements contained in this Manual.
An intent to change a sub-supplier shall be communicated well in advance to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA). The change of a sub-
supplier can only be implemented upon prior approval by Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA). See section 6.1.2 – Change Notification
across the Supply Chain. Subsequently, Production Part Approval Process (PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process)) shall be performed.
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) reserves the right to participate in audits and assessments of sub-suppliers regarding quality
management systems, processes, products etc. jointly with the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) supplier, Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) ’s customers or a third
party assigned by Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA). Advance notice will be given. Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) participation in a sub-supplier audit does not
absolve the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) supplier from their responsibility to properly monitor and develop the sub-supplier

7. Performance Measurements and Corrective Actions
Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) recognizes that the performance of the supply base has a direct and immediate impact on organizational
performance. In response to this, Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) has developed a system for the measurement and evaluation of
supplier performance. The indicators resulting from this process are compiled every month and are reviewed
and evaluated at all levels of the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) organization. These measurements are shared by Category SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer), for HIS (High Impact Supplier )
review.
7.1 Non-conforming Material and Corrective Action Response
It is in the interest of both Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) and the supplier, to identify and address non-conforming parts as quickly as
possible. Suppliers shall take all necessary actions to respond to non-conforming product that reach a Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA)
facility (production site, warehouse, etc.). Every effort is taken to investigate and document non-
conformances and to notify the supplier immediately.

Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) resulting from a non-conformance, such as the costs associated with tear down, reassembly, re-testing,
and logistics support.
7.1.1 Treatment of Complaints / Rejections
The supplier is responsible for the quality of parts/products delivered at all times, starting from nomination of
the supplier until end of project/product lifetime, EOP + 15 years (or other defined on SoW (Statement of Work)). Supplier  is also
responsible for delivery of the correct parts / products, to the correct Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) location. The supplier’s
responsibility is not only for his individual part, but also for any concerns / rejections / recalls etc. with Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA)
products/ parts which have been produced using supplier’s defect / suspect product/parts and are related to
those defect / suspect product /parts. Whenever a quality concern has occurred, the next three deliveries,
with conformance confirmed, must be identified with an extra green label.
7.1.2 Treatment of Quality & Logistic Complaints / Rejections
The supplier shall apply the eight disciplines (8D) root cause analysis problem solving methodology and have
evidence of official training on problem solving techniques.
The supplier must provide to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) facilities an 8D report which must be in the English language, and which
upon closure, clearly defines and verifies corrective actions implemented to eliminate the root cause.
This process must be carried by the supplier using the web-based Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for
Components (GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components)) (https://gpdb.yazaki-europe.com/sm_apps/). Supplier  GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components) manual is posted in the
portal, ASL (All Supplier  List dBase)-MPF Web Interface 2.6.73 (gpdbweb.azurefd.net), if necessary, further guidance / advice on the
correct use of this system can be obtained from the SQA (Supplier  Quality Assurance Engineer) and/or SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer).
7.1.3 Responsiveness / Pro-Activeness
Suppliers are selected because of their competence, qualification and particular commodity experience in an
automotive environment. This includes that suppliers must be responsive and proactive for the entire life of
the product.
Design and Development phase:
Supplier  is responsible to mention risks, advantages and disadvantages related to possible tools during RFQ (Request for Quotation)
negotations related to their investment proposals.
Suppliers must assist Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) project teams to find the best technical solutions at competitive prices, without
compromising the required level of quality.
Production phase:
Suppliers must be committed to provide the necessary resources to resolve any concerns as top priority.
Post-production phase:
Suppliers must be committed to support and take responsibility for any concerns occurring after production
phase i.e. field claims, warranty concerns.
EA-QM-xx-M-740, Rev New, 11/12/2024

7.1.4 Immediate Corrective Action
The supplier shall name a ´Champion´, who is the responsible contact person, for each supplier manufacturing
location. When Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) and associated companies receive products from more than one supplier manufacturing
location, the supplier shall name a European coordinator to assist communication.
Production flow interruption: In the event of non-conformities, the supplier must provide corrective actions
necessary to ensure Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) production without interruption. These actions may include sorting, rework,
containment, immediate replacement of defectives, and identification of `OK` parts / materials, and the
presence of the supplier’s personnel in the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) facilities affected, at supplier´s cost. Suppliers must respond
within 24 hours (maximum) when notified of a concern.
Agreed containment action may include visits of specific supplier personnel to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) facilities to review /
analyze the concerns. This is in addition to supplier personnel who may be carrying out sort / rework activities,
as referred to above.
Suppliers shall provide Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) with an initial 8D root cause analysis report using the GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components) portal, identifying
containment actions (3D) within 24 hours. The appropriate Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) SQA (Supplier  Quality Assurance Engineer) personnel responsible for handling the
concern must review and approve the proposed supplier actions.
7.1.5 Permanent Corrective Action
Suppliers must provide Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) with 8D root cause analysis, using appropriate Quality Tools, as 5 Whys or
Ishikawa Diagram, the report must be submitted within 10 working days with an 8D report detailing complete
corrective action.
A corrective action-timing plan (in conjunction with 7.1.4 above), must be submitted to the appropriate SQA (Supplier  Quality Assurance Engineer)
personnel, who must approve the proposed plan / actions.
7.1.6 Customer Line Returns, Warranty Returns to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) and NTF Process
If supplier responsibility is identified, customer line returns and warranty returns will be managed as quality
incidents and reported in the GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components) portal. The same process applies as explained in section 7.1.1. For
warranty/field claims, supplier is still responsible for their components even project is end of life, EOP +15
years (or other period mention on SoW (Statement of Work)).
If no defects or reasons for breakdown are found after performing the damaged part analysis, Supplier  shall
agree to perform an NTF process as per VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) volume Damaged part analysis field and/or OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) applicable
standards. The NTF process serves to find the cause of a problem not identified in a damaged part analysis.
7.1.7 Repetitive Problems
A repetitive problem indicates that the corrective actions according to 8D report were not effective or not
implemented. Moreover, the effectiveness of the corrective action was not verified, as required by the 8D
process.
In the case of repetitive problems, Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) may request supplier’s senior management to visit the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Plant
to propose and commit to a complete business action plan.
Supplier  shall provide 100% inspection and identification of purchased parts /products until the problem is
eliminated (Controlled Shipping), and if requested by Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA), must agree to a process audit at the relevant
supplier facility.
EA-QM-xx-M-740, Rev New, 11/12/2024
